html:
PC Number Date Chapter Chapter Year Bill Dept
 2024-13232024-12-16FIN
ActProceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act
SubjectRegulations Amending Certain Regulations Made Under the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act
PrecisRegulations amending CERTAIN REGULATIONS MADE UNDER THE PROCEEDS OF CRIME (MONEY LAUNDERING) AND TERRORIST FINANCING ACT in order to (1) extend application of Canada's anti-money laundering and anti-terrorist financing (AML/ATF) regime to the white-label ATM sector by requiring acquirers offering cash withdrawal services to white-label ATMs to meet record keeping and the Financial Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre of Canada (FINTRAC) reporting requirements; (2) expand the application of the AML/ATF regime within the real estate sector by requiring title insurers to develop an AML/ATF compliance program, meet identity verification and recordkeeping requirements, submit reports to FINTRAC such as suspicious transaction reports and follow ministerial directives; and (3) strengthen casino disbursement reporting by requiring casinos to report on the ultimate beneficiary of casino disbursements of $10,000 or more.
RegistrationRegistration: SOR/ 2024-0267 Publication Date: 2025-01-01
AttachmentsAttachment
precis: Regulations amending CERTAIN REGULATIONS MADE UNDER THE PROCEEDS OF CRIME (MONEY LAUNDERING) AND TERRORIST FINANCING ACT in order to (1) extend application of Canada's anti-money laundering and anti-terrorist financing (AML/ATF) regime to the white-label ATM sector by requiring acquirers offering cash withdrawal services to white-label ATMs to meet record keeping and the Financial Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre of Canada (FINTRAC) reporting requirements; (2) expand the application of the AML/ATF regime within the real estate sector by requiring title insurers to develop an AML/ATF compliance program, meet identity verification and recordkeeping requirements, submit reports to FINTRAC such as suspicious transaction reports and follow ministerial directives; and (3) strengthen casino disbursement reporting by requiring casinos to report on the ultimate beneficiary of casino disbursements of $10,000 or more.
